title: How to find good freelance writing jobs - Quora

response.answer_text: By not following 90% of the “advice” in the link. That’s a bunch of hooey. I’m a magazine editor, and I’ve used freelancers for more than 20 years. (I’ve also freelanced.) During a typical year, we’ll need about 24 freelance articles. Our pay—based on the writer’s ability, experience, the difficulty of the article, and other factors—ranges from 50 cents to $1.00 a word. We run articles from 1,500 to 3,500 words, so we’ll pay, on average, $1,000-$2,500 an article. In other words, we’re real. Actually getting freelance writing jobs is fairly simple: Identify a niche, or multiple niches: Sports. Healthcare. Technology. Human resources. Science and the environment. Transportation regulation. Small business. TV celebrities. Build a portfolio of articles. You may be faced with the “chicken or the egg” conundrum. Without a portfolio, how do you get assignments? Well, you get them by identifying several publications that run the sort of articles you can write. Aim for the smaller ones, likely with little or no budget. Be persistent. You’ll get an assignment. Do a good job on the assignment. Turn in a clean article that matches what the editor asked for. And turn it in on time. Keep at it until you have 8–10 or so good published articles. Now identify the next tier up. Those are the publications with at least a moderate budget. Get familiar with those publications—what sorts of articles they run, the lengths, the “voice” of the author, and so on. Next: Contact the editor, or whoever makes the article assignments. Have some ideas you can pitch. Don’t expect those to be accepted, but that’ll demonstrate you have a feel for the publication . . . and that you’ve actually looked at it. It’s very likely the magazine has an editorial calendar with articles scheduled for the next year. What you really want is for the editor to assign you one of those articles. Be persistent. The editor will ask for samples of your articles. If you have a website, you can provide a link. If you have a Dropbox account or similar, you can give that out. Or you can pick and choose and then email selected articles to the editor. You’ll also send a resume. Then stay in touch. I don’t mind an email once every 3–4 weeks. Maybe a phone call once a month. Different editors will have different preferences. Remember that editorial calendar I mentioned above? Sometimes articles get inserted, killed, or shuffled around. Last week, the editor may have though everything was scheduled. Then an article got killed or moved, and he/she has to scramble to get another one written. If you happen to call when the editor is looking, your chances go way up. Be consistently good. When you get an assignment, do a good job on it. Turn it in on deadline or before. (I like before, but if the deadline is March 15 and the article comes in on March 15, I’m happy.) If the editor considers you to be dependable and a good writer—and you stay in touch—you’ll keep getting assignments. Join one or more groups that represent freelance writers. You’ll get a lot of good information and leads from them. I said above that 90% of what’s contained in that link is hooey. Here are just a few examples: In discussing resumes/CVs, the posting says: “It can also help to broaden your search to include terms such as ‘remote writer’, ‘contract writer’, ‘copywriter’, ‘sales writer’, ‘SEO writer’, ‘content writer’ and ‘digital content’.” Those are different roles requiring different skills. An “SEO writer,” for instance, isn’t writing for a person; he/she is writing for web spiders. The SEO copy I’ve seen is almost unreadable. And I have no idea what a “remote writer” even is. Focus on the areas you’re actually good at. Don’t pretend you’re something you’re not.“Set up your own website. Having a website shows your professionalism and can be used as an example of your writing. A website also makes you more accessible as a freelancer because businesses can get in direct contact with you.” A couple of the freelancers I use have their own websites. Most don’t. As for making you more accessible “because business can get in direct contact with you,” I’ve found that the phone or email works just fine.What you need: “PayPal account – PayPal is the most common way clients will pay you for your business and it is completely free to set up an account.” Huh? A PayPal account is fine. But in 20 years, I’ve never paid a single writer via PayPal. I don’t think I’m an exception.Those are a few tips on becoming a freelance writer.

The best freelance writing jobs aren’t posted online. They come through inbound requests, and more specifically, referrals. But, if you have little to no experience and you don’t have the luxury of inbound prospects or existing customers, where do you start? A list of tactics is a start but it doesn’t really tell you what you should be doing on a daily basis to generate business. Here are some steps you can take to get started. Define your Unique Selling Proposition and Positioning - What do you offer that other freelancers don’t? You need to identify your ideal customer and figure out how you can solve their problem better than anyone else. Don’t be a generalist. Be a specialist. This will help you stand out from the crowd of other freelancers.Create an informative and professional website - Have a “home base” that prospects can use to learn about you before they reach out to inquire about your services. As soon as your website loads on their computer/phone/etc. it should immediately show your value (USP) and inform them of how you can help them. Work samples are mandatory and testimonials are very helpful.Create a super simple sales funnel to build a reliable pipeline for your business - Prospecting is like shaving. If you don’t do it every day, pretty soon you look like a bum. What you need to do now is create and execute a simple system for getting clients. The simpler the better. All you need to do is two things. (1) Generate traffic to your website with cold email, social media, using job boards, etc. and (2) convert a percentage of that traffic into a phone call, email, opt-in, etc. You must have a reliable method (or methods) of getting in front of prospects and starting a conversation with them. The traffic generation strategy you choose is dependent on your skills, what you prefer, and ultimately what provides results for you.Create an ascension and referral program - Acquiring a customer is the hardest part. Once you’ve gained that customer, you should offer them more expensive and more valuable services and preferably ones that have a continuity component, i.e., a retainer. Once your customer is happy, ask them if they know anyone else that could benefit for your service.Rinse and repeat
